text:
Let me begin, because we've
got so much to talk about,

by introducing
Professor Joe Badaracco. So Joe, let's see, we
have to bring you in.

There you are. Here I am. Welcome, we're so
glad you're here. Glad to be here, Deb.

It is a great pleasure
to have you join us. Joe is the John Shad
Professor of Business Ethics

here at Harvard
Business School, and he is a beloved professor who
teaches courses on business

ethics, on strategy, and
management in both our MBA and our executive Ed programs.

He's a graduate of
St. Louis University, also of Oxford University
where he was a Rhodes scholar,

and then of Harvard
Business School where he earned both his MBA and DPA.

He's had a wide number
of administrative posts. In fact, Joe, I don't
know if you remember, you were the head of the MBA
program when I first started.

And I interviewed you
to learn about the MBA and how the library could
support the program, et cetera.

So you were one of
the first people that I met when I came
here like 15-ish years ago.

Anyway, Joe brings a wide range
of administrative and board experience to his research.

Which he's been focused
recently on reflection and how people who have
incredible responsibilities

and hard, hard decisions to
make, both professionally and personally, how
they use reflection.

And juggle this
complex work situation when there never seems to
be enough time in the day.

Joe has an extensive research
and publication profile. And so I'm not going to
go through all of that.

But we'll put the link in the
chat to Joe's research page,

and that can lead you right
into all of his publications, and to Working Knowledge, which
will have a number of profiles

of his work. But I do want to read just
a couple of the book titles that you've published recently,
because I think we can

see a progression in your work. So one, Defining
Moments, When Managers

Must Choose Between
Right and Right, Leading Quietly, an Unorthodox
Guide to Doing the Right

Thing, Questions of Character,
and the Good Struggle, Responsible Leadership
in an Unforgiving World.

So I think you can see
where Professor Badaracco work has been and is going.

So we're just delighted
to have you here to talk about your latest
book, which is Step Back,

How to Bring the Art of
Reflection Into Your Busy Life. So Joe, let's dive in.

You begin the book by
acknowledging how difficult it is to practice
reflection, especially

in this really fast-paced
environment, where people feel they just don't have enough
time to get everything done.

Where the mantra is a
focus on productivity and the kaizen idea of strive,
strive, strive, and do, do, do.

You underscore the
importance of reflection. In fact, you start
off by telling the story of a CEO who
would double his employees

salaries if he caught them
sitting with their feet, I've got a window right here, caught
them putting their feet up

on the windowsill and
gazing out the window. And what you recommend is a
way to embrace reflection,

is to think about it a little
differently in what you call mosaic reflection.

Can you tell us, what do you
mean by mosaic reflection? Sure. Just a bit of
background about what

led me to the mosaic approach. I think, like most people,
my view of reflection

was something you
do in solitude, in a tranquil setting, for
an extended period of time.

It's like going up
to the mountain. And my question that
started me down this path

was what to really busy
people do, if anything? Maybe they don't reflect.

But if they do reflect, sort
of when and how do they do it? And I was motivated to do
this, because like many

of my colleagues, I
often would recommend to students and others that
they spend time reflecting.

Without ever
saying, this is what it is, this is how
you do it, and this

is how you find time to do it. So I interviewed about 100
busy people, mostly managers,

mostly in businesses,
and asked them what they thought reflection
was, when they did it, and so forth.

And what I discovered
was that they rarely did anything it looked like
going up to the mountain.

What they did was find small
bits of time here and there.

And each person had their
own distinctive pattern of small bits of time.

And so that's why
I called it mosaic, because a mosaic is created out
of little tiles or fragments.

And that describes
the way busy people manage to do some reflecting.

Yeah. So well, why don't we ask
our participants that,

as you're sitting here
thinking about this, what are some examples of
those little bits of time

that you take? Or when you may just have a
moment to put your feet up on the window sill.

What does that look like? So you can use chat and just,
if you put into all panelists

and to everyone, then
we can all see it. So go ahead and while
we're talking away

put in things like,
oh, here's Collette, she says she's at the gym
and during commuting time.

So that's a great idea. When I'm walking my dog. Daily walks. There's another, we've got a
lot of dog walkers on this one.

So people are, yeah,
go ahead and put in. That'll be fun for
us to come back to.

Anyway, so when you
talk about the mosaic you'll also give us a framework,
and you outline some design

principles that I
think are, again, that are a great way to think
about how we might do this.

So the first thing you talk
about is aim for the good. And at Harvard
Business School the bar

is pretty high here for
what a standard of good is.

So are you thinking about the
law of diminishing returns? Is this part of
what is good enough?

And the other question
I have and maybe you can weave these two together,
is you talk about monkey minds,

and how busy our brains are. You talk about this whole
ecosystem of our minds

and our brains
that are hardwired into our nervous system. So can you talk
to us a little bit

about what do you mean
by aim for the good? Sure, let me start actually
with the second part of what

you mentioned, then I'll come
to a good enough approach. The standard explanation
of why people

don't spend more
time reflecting today often involve blaming the
internet and smartphone,

and ubiquitous, seductive
technology in some way. And that's true.

But you can go back and read
people who are writing 100, 200 years ago, and they
were concerned about being

too busy and too distracted. So there are other
reasons why people don't find time to reflect.

I'm not going to spend
a lot of time on these. Some people feel they've got
to be productive all the time.

A lot of people have really
serious responsibilities and they want to do them well.

Some people are
afraid to reflect, because they're afraid
where it might take them.

And then there is what
you refer to, Deb, which is how our minds work. And this idea that our
minds are monkey minds.

It actually goes back to
the Buddhist tradition thousands of years ago, that
our brains just leap around.

And that might have been because
our ancient ancestors, whose brains leaped around, were
more likely to survive,

because they were looking
here for sabertooth tigers and there for poisonous insects. So our brains just
seem to work that way.

So the approach to the first
of these design principles that I recommend, the
first of the four,

is just aim for good enough. There's an old saying,
the better or the perfect

is the enemy of the good. And you've got people who do,
as you say, have high standards.

And if there's something
you feel you should do, and you ought to
do it really well, and you just aren't
doing it that way,

there's a good chance
you're going to give up. So by good enough reflection,
I mean you do it most days,

you do it pretty well,
you feel like you're making some progress.

That's great. Don't feel it's got to be every
day, certain period of time, and you end the period
with some great insight

into your life or your work
or something like that. There's old saying, if
a thing's worth doing,

it's worth doing well. There are some other things
that I think are worth doing, even if you can't do them
well most of the time.

But give it a shot. And I put reflection
in that category.

You also talk about, you give
us some real physical things to do. Again, like connecting
our body and our minds.

And you talk about some of
these overcoming the obstacles to reflecting.

Things like, you
call it piggyback reflecting and writing.

So tell us a little bit more
about how you found people doing this.

This is one of the
things I discovered as I did the interviews
and found out what people were actually doing.

And what I discovered
is that there was often a physical component
to the reflection.

It was captured in a comment
by the venture capitalist you refer to, who said, when he
was talking to the people who

his firm had invested in. They were particularly young
people, running startups, they were putting out
fires all the time.

And he talked
about, he said, I'm going to double your salary. He put it in a way that
sounded like a threat at first.

He said, if I ever
come into your office and find you with your feet
up on the desk looking out

the window, I'm going
to double your salary. And the point he was making
is it's really hard to do it,

it's really worthwhile, but it's
not just mental, it's physical. Put your feet up and
look out the window.

So I noticed a number of the
chat comments that went by, people talked about
doing things physically.

Running, being at the gym. That was true for some
people, not everybody, but for some people
it really worked.

A few people would even
assign questions of themselves at the beginning
of a run, and then

see where they were
at the end of the run. There's a long
tradition of prayer,

in the Western tradition,
involves kneeling basically. And in the Eastern
tradition, you

have yoga and lotus position
and other meditative positions.

We're not disembodied spirits. You can't just flip
a switch and go

from thinking one type of thing
to a more reflective thought. You often have to
move your body, which

is what your brain and nervous
system are embedded in. And in many cases that
means just getting away

from your laptop. Because you see the
laptop and we're like Pavlovian rodents and
it's time to go to work.

Yeah, it is. When we were talking earlier
about Ashley Whillan's book

about Time Smart. And a lot of her recommendations
were just put down the phone,

just move away from it. But this notion of physical,
I think you're right, the very first one in
was, I go to the gym.

But it is this act of
doing something different, not just being totally
within your brain.

Exactly. It often, and I guess as I think
back now in almost every case,

there was a physical
accompaniment to the wide range of ways
in which people reflected.

That's interesting. So then within this framework,
you talk about three sections.

And actually the book is
arranged that way basically. As the introduction
moves to the framework,

and then to these three
additional principles. And I thought it would
be good to give people

a grounding in what those
design principles are. So the first one you
talk about is downshift.

And I suppose there is
a physicality to that, too, because if I'm
thinking about a car, if I'm downshifting it
really a physical movement.

And you outline what you
call mental meandering

and celebrating were two of the
two that piqued my curiosity. I'm a list-making enthusiast.

I'm one of these people,
like many I think listening, is that I might write
something down on a list that I already did just
so I could cross it off.

So slightly crazy. But you also talk about
Mark Anderson's use

of the anti-to-do list, which,
again, I found intriguing. And the white rabbit statement
in the Disney version

of Alice in Wonderland, which
is don't just do something, stand there.

Which it sort of seems
the opposite of the Nike school of just do it.

So tell us a little
bit about what are some of the
downshifting elements.

Let me start by
just saying where this notion of
downshifting come from. So A, it's not something
I invented or heard

in the interviews. And also I should mention that
it's not mindfulness meditation

either. I was surprised actually
at how few of the people I interviewed did
mindfulness meditation.

Most of them liked
it and tried it, they said they didn't
have much time for it. The origin of this approach that
I called downshifting really,

for centuries it was
called contemplation. And it goes back, the templa
is like the Roman temple

where a priest would go to
interpret signals or messages

from the gods. So it's a matter of, as
one interviewee put it,

getting this notion of
productivity out of your head. This notion of knocking
off the next item

on the list for
just a little while. Now some people said
that when they did this,

they let their minds just run,
and they often turned either

to things they were feeling
that they hadn't really noticed, because they were busy.

Thoughts that had been
pushed out of their heads, because they were focused
on task, task, task.

Or sometimes on things
going on around them, people around them. But our brains are often
sort of like lasers

and we focus on this,
and this, and this. This is letting that go.

But then other people said, that
might be great for some people, it drives me crazy.

I can't do that. If I'm going to let my mind
go, it's got to go somewhere.

And something involving
nature was often mentioned.

Which, by the way, can
be a nice nature scene or video on YouTube. It could also be
looking out the window,

as in if I catch you with your
feet up looking out the window. And then celebrate was one
that a few people referred to.

And it came from
one guy, who you could tell was a really
hardworking, driven individual.

And he's the one who referred
to the Japanese just in time, continuous improvement system is
a great way to run a business.

But he also said, it's
a terrible way to live. And he said, from time to time,
he said, you just need to stop,

and if you or your team has
done something well, even if it's small, then just stop.

He said, rub the certificate,
pat yourself on the back, say we did a great job.

Everybody's going
to go back to work, because that's what we do. So don't view the little break
is dangerous, but take time

occasionally to celebrate. And that's just another
way of freeing your mind from task, task, task.

And it's really experiencing
either something going on inside you, or going
on around you, that you may not

be paying enough attention to. And see what it is. See if you want to
spend some time on it.

It doesn't have any
purpose beyond that. It's just living for
a couple minutes.

Take that, again, the
mosaic theme, of it doesn't have to be a
big walking the Camino,

or climbing Kilimanjaro, or
something that is a huge task. But it can be these
small bits of activity.

But let me add something
to that, Deborah. And this is really
important, because we've got these challenges.

The internet, productivity,
serious responsibilities.

People found their
own pattern of these small mosaic activities.

And the advice in the book
is to observe yourself for a little while,
and just see at what

points in the day, or the
week, just naturally you step back from your to-do list.

And you can free
yourself up a little bit to do one of the three
kinds of reflection

that I described in the book. And the first is downshifting. But you have to
observe yourself.

Like some of the people
in chat who said, well, I noticed I do it
when I'm taking a shower. Or I do it when I'm at the gym.

Or I do, somebody said they
were playing a particular game or something. Playing golf.

You've got to observe yourself. And by the way, if you find
times when you do it naturally

and you can build on
those and repeat those, then it's not a struggle. It's not an act of virtue, and
discipline, and all that stuff.

But you've got to observe
yourself and see when you do step back a little bit. That's an act of reflection,
even in observing yourself.

It is, it is. So from the notion
of downshifting,

and I get a feel that these
four build on each other. Now we're moving into how do
we ponder the tough issues.

So we're getting
some intensification here on strategic
decisions and life choices

that you start talking about. Another thing I love about
the book is that you've spent,

and we'll talk
about this in a bit, but you have spent an
enormous amount of time looking at the literature. Not just literature
on reflection,

but broad literature of diaries,
and journaling, and writing,

and meditating, and all
kinds of different aspects. And you comment
on Proust saying,

the true art of discovery
wasn't discovering new lands, but seeing things with new eyes.

So when we have these
really tough decisions that we have to
make, how can you

help us think through those? Let me go back, Deb, and
just put something else

in front of everyone listening. You triggered this. I did rely on much more
than the interviews.

There's traditions of
reflection in the East and the West that
go back a long ways.

And there's some
classics of reflection. So if we come back
to this question of good enough reflection.

One of the classics in
the Western tradition is the meditations
of Marcus Aurelius.

He was a Roman emperor. He wasn't in Rome
enjoying himself, he spent the last
10 years of his life

in miserable conditions
in northern Italy, leading soldiers in a war,
while people were scheming

and plotting against
him back in Rome. And when he had
little bits of time

he wrote what was
essentially a diary. It's amazing that it
survived and we have it.

And the original title
of this was To Himself. And these were
just small moments,

his own mosaic pattern, where
he stepped back and reflected a little bit. So these three basic
approaches I described really

do have deep roots. Now this one called pondering
is when you've got a big issue,

but you can use it
for small issues. People used to go
to restaurants, some people still
do, used to do it

without a lot of forethought
and planning and masks. But if you've got to make
any kind of decision,

big or small, pondering
says, wait a minute, I'm not going to follow
my first instinct here.

I'm going to spend
a few minutes trying to look at it from a variety
of different perspectives.

And see if there's
complexities I missed. See if there are facets
of it that I ought

to spend a little more time on. See if there are things
that are actually, once I look at it in
a variety of ways,

I find a little disturbing
and I need to drill down on a little bit more.

And what I picked
up from the people I interviewed were a variety
of ways of doing this.

One that sticks with me,
that I think is really good, is you've got a couple
different options.

to actually implement
that option. What are you going to be doing? Who's going to be doing it?

What's it going to feel like? How are other people
going to react? This is triggering your
imagination and your feelings

to some extent,
which may come out of the scenarios you imagine. As opposed to just
saying, well, I've

done cost benefit analysis,
this is the winner. Let's go ahead with it. So it's sort of
like a wood carver

turning something
over on a lathe and just working on
it for a little while. A little while might be
five minutes, 15 minutes.

But usually the
problems that get to people with serious
responsibilities are complicated.

And they're
multifaceted, and you've got to try to look at
those different facets, and do it purposefully.

You also talk about having
conversations with yourself. So I think, again, this
notion that I'm always

intrigued with, if it's me,
myself, and I in a room, who wins out in
the conversation?

The classic, go to
the mountain approach tends to be solitary reflection.

And I would say about
a third of the people I interviewed said they
reflected really well

talking with someone else. And it wasn't just anyone else. But at work, or in the
rest of their lives,

there was somebody when
they talk with them there was just a different climate.

A sense of connection,
a sense of trust. And when they had
something they wanted

to really look at in
more depth, or ponder, they'd find five or 10 minutes
to go down the hallway,

back when we went down hallways,
and knock on somebody's door and talk with them
about a little bit.

So it was conversational. But three or four
people found what

really helped was talking with
themselves or to themselves. They said they staged back
and forth conversations.

You probably don't want to do
that while you're in public.

Walking back from the
water cooler or whatever, it could trigger all sorts of
stuff, conversations about you.

But if you go back in
the Western tradition,

the original way of
dealing with heart problems was the platonic dialogue.

That was Plato conversing
with other people. So conversational reflection
is another departure

from the classic model. And if you just
stop and, as I said, observe your life a little bit.

And if you find there's
a couple of people you can really talk with,
as a reflective, thoughtful

conversation, make sure
you go to them when you've got something you
want to deal with next time.

And then the fourth, and I
know I'm moving very quickly,

but I also want to
make sure that we get to people's
questions, because there will be lots of them.

That fourth layer, or the third
approach that you talk about is called pause and measure up.

And I was thinking as
I was reading the book, I was wondering if there were
either gender, or age related,

or if there were characteristics
that maybe this group looks at things this
way, and that group looks at things another way.

Do we have stereotypical
characteristics? And then you open the last
chapter with showing how

two very different people,
an older, white person, male,

and then a younger,
ethnic person. And they both came up
with the same questions, and they were
slightly different,

but they were very similar. So the one said,
and I want to make sure I get this right, is
that they would ask themselves

this question, what am I doing
that I should stop doing? And what am I doing
that I should be doing?

And the other person said,
their approach was to say, what I have been doing,
and what I should be doing.

So we had two different age
groups, genders, ethnicities, same kind of approach.

These were both
managers and they had been managers for a while. And the focus was on doing,
and that's no surprise.

There's a way you
can take this focus, this third classic
approach to reflection,

which I call measuring up. And before I describe
it, let me just compare it to the other two.

The first one, downshifting,
is sort of just being.

Pondering is a
version of thinking. And this last one
is about doing.

And if you think about
being, thinking, and doing, it's how we spend all our time.

We may have the mix
wrong, whatever, but that's what
human creatures do.

And so this last
approach is really not just to figure
something out by pondering,

I've got to do A, B, or C.
And the idea of measuring up

is you certainly
want to do whatever the relevant analysis is. Cost benefit, know
run big data, talk

to experts, and all the rest. But before you make a decision,
just step back a little bit

and say, are you measuring up in
terms of the broader standards that other people have for you?

People you work with,
people you report to, larger standards, not just
getting the task right,

and the standards you
have for yourself. So that's what you
try to measure up to.

And it's measuring
without a yardstick. But it's just saying, wait
a minute, longer term,

bigger picture, am I
meeting these standards?

I was thinking about, when
you said take a step back, and I think how, again, in a
very busy and complex world,

is that how far back? And if we're near
a cliff we have

to be a little careful
about how far back we go. But when you're thinking
about that, is taking a step,

again, is that a physical? Is it a, what do
you think there? Well, two things. First, it's a physical step.
One person put it very well.

He said, you just can't
go home and flip a switch and say, I'm going to be
reflective for the next hour or so.

Somebody also said that
if you take the stereotype or caricature of
managers in the '50s,

you're white, American males
running big corporations, they would go home and
have a couple of martinis.

So that was a way of just
maybe changing physically,

maybe not as good for
you as going to the gym, but it changed your
psyche a little bit. You've got to do
something like that.

The book ends, however, by
saying that sometimes you've got to step back further.

And if you've got
a big decision, you do have to spend more
than just a few minutes on it.

And all of the people
virtually I interviewed said that they felt they should,
every couple of weeks, spend

not just five minutes here or
10 minutes there, a moment here,

but a half an hour or an hour. And spend that being,
thinking, doing, either

in terms of
downshifting, pondering, or are they really measuring up.

So this classic notion of
reflection, go to the mountain, it's been around
for a long time.

It's got some truth to it. And you can't do
everything in a microwave.

Sometimes you got to
put it in the oven and let it bake for a while.

So Joe, I want to make sure
we get to our participants questions, so I'll
give them just

a second to start getting
your questions into chat that we'll take. But while people are
putting their questions in,

let me ask you a little
bit about the book. I told you I was going to
ask him, being a librarian, I love books.

And so if I think about
the book as an artifact. One of the things I
loved about this book,

and I know these are
conscious decisions, so I wondered if you would
tell us a little bit about it. This is a little book.

It fits in my hand. I think, when we were
first talking about this,
it goes this way. It's small, it fits. Show the spine.

Oh, right, so it's not. It reminds me, I'm also
reading the book on Vinci,

and I don't read it at night,
because I'll knock myself out

if it falls over. So tell us about, because I know
you did extensive literature

review, you have thousands and
thousands of pages of notes.

How did you boil
it down to this? Painfully.

And slowly. Yeah, I had about 700 or 800
pages of single spaced notes

that I took on reflection,
in all its dimensions. Classic examples of
reflections, Montaigne's essays,

the meditations of
Marcus Aurelius, Spiritual Exercises
of Ignatius of Loyola, and I read about
those texts as well.

And I took notes, because
I was really interested. And then I had a couple
thousand pages of transcripts from the interview.

And the first step
was just to try to organize it and
see what fit together and what pattern emerged.

But at that point it was
hundreds, and hundreds, and hundreds of pages. But I wanted a
book that somebody

could sit down, read easily. I think a couple of years
ago Amazon had a program,

I think it was Amazon,
you could put in like a couple words of
prose, copy and paste it in,

and it would tell you
what educational level that prose was aimed.

And I came out around
sophomore in high school. And I thought,
that's pretty good.

That means people can read what
I've written and understand it. So I really tried to make
this short and accessible.

Folks just don't have
time for tomes these days. No, it's really tough.

But we do have a few questions,
so let's dive into them. So one person, Lucas says,
thinking, reflection,

mediation. How do you discern amongst these
different types of activities?

And do they all build
together into this mosaic? Or what do you think.

Well, if you really
want to be systematic, and some people were. They would say, look,
when I want to reflect,

I first of all spend a little
bit of time downshifting just to clear my mind. And then if I'm
working on a problem

and I've got to make a
decision, I will ponder it, look at it in different ways.

Some people doodled
on blackboards. Some people doodled on paper. Some people went and
talked to somebody.

And then they said,
OK, I've got to decide. If I look at as a technical
problem, what am I going to do?

And then they put it
against this larger standard of measuring up. So you can do it that way.

But each one of these
approaches to reflection is worth doing in and of itself.

They're probably going to
make for better decisions and make for better living.

So I think in a good
week or so you've spent a little time
downshifting, and pondering,

and seeing if
you're measuring up.  Another person says
that you've talked

a lot about different ways
to practice reflecting. And are there any practices that
you have picked up personally
since writing the book? Well, yes. You mentioned Marcel Proust.

He also said, and
